ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really had a blast in this course. Really helped me with thinking theoretically about disposession. At the same time, learned plenty about craft of ethnographic writing, and how to make it less obtuse.
I learned how to be a better student, how to synthesize disparate texts into fitting the broader themes of a course, and gained some perspective on current affairs around the world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Really cool focus, liked the casual atmosphere a lot. The syllabus was great, but the longer denser works should have came earlier in the semester, I think.

The course organization was great. My one suggestion would be carving out more time at the end of the course for full student presentations. Maybe eliminate the theory paper in the first part and instead get students launched on their projects sooner so they can present and have some more discussion of their own land-grab case studies. That really gets students to apply the theory and other readings to their own topic...pushing thinking in an applied context.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, with the caveat that they must enjoy theoretical work as well as practical case studies.
